title: Quirky 1970's inline display face
author: osamu

comments.content:
I can't find this /R/S or /c in a digital font, but look at the following travesties(?), matching "Upperville" to help with your inquiry:

Xippy (no more info),  
Tatum (Freeware! from A. Carr),  
Tolum (Freeware! from A. Carr)  
Tahitelbait (no more info),  
Oneil (no more info),  
Daubler (1994, by CompuWorks)  
Core 1, Core 3, Core 5, Core 7 (Cambridge Fontworks)  
Uptown (Copyright (c) 1992 Corel Corporation)  
Uptight Neon (Copyright (c) 1992 Corel Corporation)  
Uptight (Copr.1992 Image Club Graphics, Inc)  
URSULINE (1997, ARC MEDIA INC)  
Downtown (©1995-2001 Arts & Letters Corporation)

Original might be an ITC font under the name of Uptight. Luc Devroye's list of Corel font name equivalences matches this with Corel's Uptown, which is far better made than an autotrace.  
 [http://luc.devroye.org/corelequivalences.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150422054731/http:/luc.devroye.org/corelequivalences.html "http://luc.devroye.org/corelequivalences.html")  
At least it's somewhere to start your search for originals.  
Don

Note in "ARIES MUSIC" that S in MUSIC matches Uptight/Uptown while S in ARIES is different. This suggests to me that R, M and C may also be modifications. The font has the elements for the R. Merely mirror the 9 and do a little editing for the leg.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150422054731im_/http:/typophile.com/files/UptightUptownRmodified_4613.jpg)
  
M, C and S are even easier to modify.  
Don

For M rotate the bowl of p 90 degrees, extend the vertical strokes, clip the inner stroke into a taper to match the other letters, mirror and use both original and mirror and this is what you get:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150422054731im_/http:/typophile.com/files/UptightUptownMmodified_3582.jpg)
  
As I mentioned in an earlier post, I suspect that these letters are not in the original font.  
Don

With the assistance of fvilanakis's list, and Don's identification of ITC Uptight I've managed to locate some possible print sources of the original.

I also now see that this request has been posted here before: [http://typophile.com/node/47014](http://web.archive.org/web/20150422054731/http:/typophile.com/node/47014)

I doubt whether a synthesizer company would be creating their own custom letters for a few print ads, and indeed the previous identifier, Mark Simonson, states that ITC Uptight Regular (as opposed to Neon) did indeed have several alternate letterforms which have been used in the samples I have posted here. Most modern sources such as Rookledge's Classic International Typefinder list only ITC Uptight Neon, not Uptight Regular. But at least now I have what I need. Thanks all!

Here is the character set of the variation known as Uptight Neon displayed in the 1985 "Letraset Product Manual," which should be easy to obtain if you wish to make a more detailed scan:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150422054731im_/http:/typophile.com/files/UptightNeonITC@letraset1985_6148.jpg)
  
I have rearranged the characters to fit the Typophile image format.  
Don

Here is [a Berthold Fototypes specimen](http://web.archive.org/web/20150422054731/https:/www.flickr.com/photos/stewf/14429815100/) of ITC Uptight and and ITC Uptight Neon. The Neon doesn’t have the alts from Don’s sample above, though.
